transcript:
and with down- cast eyes. What she found hardest to bear was to know that on such occasions she ought to be- have like Mademoiselle Bourienne, but could not. She thought: "If I seem not to notice he will think that I do not sympathize with him; if I seem sad and out of spirits myself, he will say (as he has done before) that I'm in thedumps." 
The prince looked at his daughter's fright- ened face and snorted. 
"Fool ... or dummy!" he muttered.
